title: 1 Samuel Chapter 10 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 10 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 10 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 10.

questions.question: What did Samuel pour upon Saul's head to anoint him?
options: Oil
Water
Wine
Milk
questions.correctAnswer: Oil
questions.explanation: Samuel took a vial of oil and poured it upon Saul's head as an anointing (1 Samuel 10:1).

questions.question: Where would Saul find two men after departing from Samuel?
options: By Rachel's sepulchre
At the plain of Tabor
On the hill of God
At Gilgal
questions.correctAnswer: By Rachel's sepulchre
questions.explanation: Samuel told Saul he would find two men by Rachel's sepulchre in the border of Benjamin at Zelzah (1 Samuel 10:2).

questions.question: What were the three men going up to God to Bethel carrying?
options: Three kids, three loaves of bread, and a bottle of wine
Three lambs, three baskets of figs, and a jar of oil
Three oxen, three sheaves of wheat, and a cup of water
Three goats, three cakes, and a bottle of milk
questions.correctAnswer: Three kids, three loaves of bread, and a bottle of wine
questions.explanation: The three men going up to God to Bethel carried three kids, three loaves of bread, and a bottle of wine (1 Samuel 10:3).

questions.question: What would the prophets be doing when Saul met them on the hill?
options: Prophesying
Fighting
Harvesting
Building
questions.correctAnswer: Prophesying
questions.explanation: A company of prophets met Saul, playing instruments and prophesying (1 Samuel 10:5).

questions.question: What would happen to Saul when the Spirit of the LORD came upon him?
options: He would prophesy and be turned into another man
He would fall asleep
He would start building an altar
He would run away
questions.correctAnswer: He would prophesy and be turned into another man
questions.explanation: The Spirit of the LORD would come upon Saul, causing him to prophesy and be changed into another man (1 Samuel 10:6).

questions.question: Where was Saul instructed to go down to after the signs came to pass?
options: Gilgal
Bethel
Zelzah
Mizpeh
questions.correctAnswer: Gilgal
questions.explanation: Samuel told Saul to go down to Gilgal where Samuel would come to offer sacrifices (1 Samuel 10:8).

questions.question: What did God give Saul after he turned his back to leave Samuel?
options: Another heart
A sword
A crown
A horse
questions.correctAnswer: Another heart
questions.explanation: God gave Saul another heart after he turned his back to go from Samuel (1 Samuel 10:9).

questions.question: What did the people say when they saw Saul prophesying among the prophets?
options: Is Saul also among the prophets?
Who is this man?
He is the chosen king
God has abandoned us
questions.correctAnswer: Is Saul also among the prophets?
questions.explanation: The people asked, "Is Saul also among the prophets?" when they saw him prophesying (1 Samuel 10:11).

questions.question: Who was taken from the tribe of Benjamin when Samuel called the people together?
options: Saul the son of Kish
David the son of Jesse
Eli the priest
Samuel the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Saul the son of Kish
questions.explanation: Saul the son of Kish was taken from the family of Matri in the tribe of Benjamin (1 Samuel 10:21).

questions.question: Where did Saul hide when they sought him among the people?
options: Among the stuff
In a cave
On the roof
In the field
questions.correctAnswer: Among the stuff
questions.explanation: The LORD said Saul had hidden himself among the stuff when they looked for him (1 Samuel 10:22).

questions.question: True or False: Saul was shorter than all the people when he stood among them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Saul was higher than any of the people from his shoulders and upward (1 Samuel 10:23).

questions.question: True or False: Samuel wrote the manner of the kingdom in a book and laid it up before the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Samuel wrote the manner of the kingdom in a book and laid it up before the LORD (1 Samuel 10:25).

questions.question: True or False: The children of Belial accepted Saul and brought him presents.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The children of Belial despised Saul and brought him no presents (1 Samuel 10:27).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Samuel said, 'Is it not because the LORD hath ______ thee to be captain over his inheritance?'
options: anointed
cursed
called
chosen
questions.correctAnswer: anointed
questions.explanation: Samuel said that the LORD had anointed Saul to be captain over his inheritance (1 Samuel 10:1).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Saul's uncle asked, 'Whither went ye?' Saul answered, 'To seek the ______.'
options: asses
sheep
goats
cattle
questions.correctAnswer: asses
questions.explanation: Saul said they went to seek the asses which were lost (1 Samuel 10:14).

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 10 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 10 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with obedience to God's guidance. Based on 1 Samuel 10, what biblical truth would you share about following God's direction?
options: Obey God's instructions even when they seem unusual or unexpected
Wait for others to lead before acting on God's word
Only obey when it benefits you personally
Ignore signs that don't make sense immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Obey God's instructions even when they seem unusual or unexpected
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 10:2-7 shows Saul receiving specific and unusual instructions from Samuel, including meeting certain people and accepting loaves of bread. Saul obeys these signs as a demonstration of trusting God's plan, illustrating the importance of obedience even when directions seem unexpected.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 10 teach us about the importance of spiritual transformation in leadership?
options: God changes the heart and empowers a leader through His Spirit
Leadership depends solely on human strength and wisdom
Leaders do not need spiritual renewal to lead well
Transformation happens only after the leader is fully established
questions.correctAnswer: God changes the heart and empowers a leader through His Spirit
questions.explanation: Verses 9 and 10 show that God gave Saul 'another heart' and the Spirit of the LORD came upon him, enabling him to prophesy and become a changed man, highlighting the necessity of divine empowerment for godly leadership.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 10 teach about humility and God's choice of leaders?
options: God often chooses individuals who may not seem impressive by worldly standards
Only noble and strong men are chosen by God
Leadership is earned through wealth and popularity
God prefers leaders who boast about their achievements
questions.correctAnswer: God often chooses individuals who may not seem impressive by worldly standards
questions.explanation: In verses 20-24, Saul is chosen from the tribe of Benjamin and was initially hidden among the stuff, yet God chose him despite his unassuming appearance, teaching humility and God's sovereign choice.

questions.question: A believer is facing doubts about God's plan for their life. Based on 1 Samuel 10, what encouragement would you offer about trusting God's timing?
options: Trust that God will reveal His plan in His timing and provide confirmation
Give up if the answer is not immediate
Make plans without seeking God's guidance
Wait passively without seeking God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God will reveal His plan in His timing and provide confirmation
questions.explanation: Samuel told Saul to wait seven days at Gilgal until Samuel came to instruct him (verse 8), demonstrating that waiting on God's timing is part of obedience and trust.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 10 illustrate the role of prayer and seeking God in decision-making?
options: Consulting God and seeking His word brings clarity and confirmation in choices
Decisions should be made solely based on human wisdom
Prayer is unnecessary if you feel confident
Waiting for others is more important than seeking God
questions.correctAnswer: Consulting God and seeking His word brings clarity and confirmation in choices
questions.explanation: In verse 22, when Saul could not be found, the people inquired of the LORD if he should come, and the LORD answered, showing the importance of prayerfully seeking God's guidance in decisions.

questions.question: What lesson about integrity and honesty can be drawn from Saul's initial search for the lost donkeys in 1 Samuel 10?
options: Attend to responsibilities honestly even before being recognized for greater roles
Ignore small duties when larger tasks arise
Only focus on important matters and neglect daily responsibilities
Deceive others to achieve your goals faster
questions.correctAnswer: Attend to responsibilities honestly even before being recognized for greater roles
questions.explanation: Saul was initially sent to find lost donkeys (verse 2), showing that faithful attention to small tasks is important and aligns with biblical integrity and stewardship principles.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 10, God's Spirit empowers believers to serve and witness effectively.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 reveal that the Spirit of the LORD will come upon Saul and he will prophesy, indicating God's Spirit empowers believers for service and witness.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 10 show the importance of fellowship and encouragement among believers?
options: The company of prophets who greeted Saul encouraged and confirmed his calling
Isolation is preferable for spiritual growth
Believers should avoid fellowship with those different from them
Encouragement is unnecessary for new leaders
questions.correctAnswer: The company of prophets who greeted Saul encouraged and confirmed his calling
questions.explanation: In verses 5 and 10, Saul meets a group of prophets who prophesy and receive him, illustrating the value of fellowship and mutual encouragement in spiritual growth.

questions.question: A new believer is feeling unworthy to serve. What does 1 Samuel 10 teach about God’s choice and use of people for His purposes?
options: God can choose and transform anyone regardless of their background
Only the most qualified can serve God
Service is reserved for the perfect
Unworthiness should prevent you from serving
questions.correctAnswer: God can choose and transform anyone regardless of their background
questions.explanation: God gave Saul a new heart (verse 9) and chose him despite his humble status (verses 20-24), showing God’s power to transform and use anyone for His purposes.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 10 teach about dealing with opposition or criticism in service to God?
options: Remain silent and trusting, even when despised or opposed
Retaliate immediately against critics
Quit service when criticized
Ignore God’s calling because of opposition
questions.correctAnswer: Remain silent and trusting, even when despised or opposed
questions.explanation: In verse 27, Saul was despised by some but he held his peace, teaching perseverance and trust in God despite opposition.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Samuel 10 indicates that God's anointing is a visible sign that confirms a person’s divine appointment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: In verse 1, Samuel anoints Saul with oil as a tangible sign that he is chosen by God to lead, demonstrating how God confirms His appointments visibly.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 10 instruct believers about the role of celebration and public acknowledgment in church life?
options: Publicly affirm and celebrate God’s chosen servants to encourage unity
Avoid public displays of faith
Ignore leaders and their roles
Celebrate only personal achievements
questions.correctAnswer: Publicly affirm and celebrate God’s chosen servants to encourage unity
questions.explanation: Verse 24 records the people shouting 'God save the king' after Samuel presented Saul, showing how public acknowledgment fosters unity and encouragement within the community.

questions.question: What biblical principle about stewardship is illustrated by Saul bringing a band of men whose hearts God had touched with him?
options: Spiritual leadership includes influencing others to serve God wholeheartedly
Leadership is a solitary responsibility
Only the leader matters in ministry
Spiritual influence is unrelated to leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual leadership includes influencing others to serve God wholeheartedly
questions.explanation: Verse 26 shows Saul going home with men whose hearts God had touched, highlighting the role of a leader in inspiring and shepherding others to faithful service.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Samuel told the people, 'Ye have this day rejected your God... and said unto him, Nay, but set a ______ over us.'
options: king
priest
prophet
judge
questions.correctAnswer: king
questions.explanation: In verse 19, Samuel explains that the people rejected God by requesting a king to rule over them, illustrating the importance of recognizing God's sovereignty.

questions.question: What practical lesson about patience and waiting on God can believers learn from Saul’s experience in 1 Samuel 10?
options: Patience is necessary while awaiting God’s instructions before acting
Act quickly without waiting for confirmation
Delay is a sign that God has abandoned you
Waiting is optional when you feel ready
questions.correctAnswer: Patience is necessary while awaiting God’s instructions before acting
questions.explanation: Samuel instructed Saul to wait seven days at Gilgal until Samuel came to him with further instructions (verse 8), teaching the value of patience in following God's timing.

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 10 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 10.

questions.question: What is the significance of Samuel pouring oil on Saul's head in 1 Samuel 10:1?
options: It signifies Saul's anointing as captain over God's inheritance
It was a common ritual for purification before battle
It marked Saul as a prophet among the people
It symbolized Saul's wealth and status
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies Saul's anointing as captain over God's inheritance
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 10:1 explains that Samuel poured oil on Saul's head as a symbol of his anointing by the LORD to be captain over His inheritance, indicating divine appointment to leadership.

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 10:2-3, Saul is told to expect encounters with certain individuals carrying specific items. What is the deeper symbolic meaning of these encounters?
options: They foreshadow Saul’s divine commissioning and his future responsibilities
They represent Saul’s loss of family wealth and status
They are a test of Saul’s obedience to Samuel
They highlight the economic activities of Israelite society
questions.correctAnswer: They foreshadow Saul’s divine commissioning and his future responsibilities
questions.explanation: The encounters with the men carrying animals, bread, and wine illustrate the unfolding of God's plan through symbolic signs, marking Saul's transition into a divinely appointed leader as described in 1 Samuel 10:2-3.

questions.question: What role do the prophets play in Saul's transformation in 1 Samuel 10:5-6?
options: They serve as a catalyst for the Spirit of the LORD to come upon Saul
They anoint Saul officially as king
They offer Saul guidance on ruling
They test Saul's loyalty to God
questions.correctAnswer: They serve as a catalyst for the Spirit of the LORD to come upon Saul
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 10:5-6, the company of prophets prophesying before Saul is the occasion for the Spirit of the LORD to come upon him, changing him into another man and marking his divine empowerment.

questions.question: How does the phrase 'God gave him another heart' in 1 Samuel 10:9 relate to the concept of divine transformation in the Old Testament?
options: It indicates a spiritual renewal and empowerment by God
It signals a physical healing of the heart
It means Saul was given a new family lineage
It implies a change in Saul's social status only
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a spiritual renewal and empowerment by God
questions.explanation: The phrase in 1 Samuel 10:9 reflects the Old Testament theme where God changes a person's heart to enable them to fulfill His purposes, similar to transformations seen in prophets like Ezekiel and kings like David.

questions.question: What literary device is used in 1 Samuel 10:11-12 when the people say, 'Is Saul also among the prophets?'
options: Irony highlighting Saul's unexpected prophetic behavior
Metaphor comparing Saul to a prophet
Hyperbole exaggerating Saul’s abilities
Simile illustrating Saul’s humility
questions.correctAnswer: Irony highlighting Saul's unexpected prophetic behavior
questions.explanation: The phrase is ironic because Saul, known as a man of humble origins, unexpectedly prophesies, challenging social expectations and creating a proverb, as seen in 1 Samuel 10:11-12.

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 10:17-19, Samuel gathers Israel to Mizpeh to declare God's response to their request for a king. What theological theme does this event emphasize?
options: The tension between divine kingship and human monarchy
The establishment of the Davidic covenant
The role of prophets as kings
The rejection of idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: The tension between divine kingship and human monarchy
questions.explanation: Samuel's speech in 1 Samuel 10:17-19 highlights Israel’s rejection of God as their direct king in favor of a human king, underscoring the tension between divine sovereignty and human political structures.

questions.question: Why was Saul initially hard to find among the tribe of Benjamin in 1 Samuel 10:21-22?
options: Because he hid himself among the stuff as the LORD had indicated
Because he was away tending the donkeys
Because he was with Samuel in private consultation
Because he was preparing for battle
questions.correctAnswer: Because he hid himself among the stuff as the LORD had indicated
questions.explanation: 1 Samuel 10:22 states that Saul hid himself among the stuff, fulfilling the LORD’s answer to the inquiry about his whereabouts, indicating humility or reluctance at his anointing.

questions.question: The phrase 'he was higher than any of the people from his shoulders and upward' in 1 Samuel 10:23 signifies what in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Physical stature as a sign of leadership and authority
A metaphor for spiritual elevation
His wealth and social rank
His prophetic anointing
questions.correctAnswer: Physical stature as a sign of leadership and authority
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, physical height often symbolized prominence and suitability for leadership, as indicated in 1 Samuel 10:23 where Saul’s height distinguished him among the people.

questions.question: What does the people's shout 'God save the king' in 1 Samuel 10:24 indicate about Israelite acceptance of monarchy?
options: They publicly acknowledge Saul as God's chosen king
They are hesitant and reluctant to accept Saul
They reject Saul in favor of another leader
They demand a different form of governance
questions.correctAnswer: They publicly acknowledge Saul as God's chosen king
questions.explanation: The shout in 1 Samuel 10:24 shows the people’s acceptance and recognition of Saul as the LORD’s anointed king, reflecting the communal endorsement of monarchy under divine sanction.

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 10:25, Samuel records the manner of the kingdom and lays it before the LORD. What is the significance of this act?
options: It establishes a covenantal framework for Israel's monarchy
It was a legal requirement for coronation
It was a record of Saul’s genealogy
It was a prophecy of Saul's reign
questions.correctAnswer: It establishes a covenantal framework for Israel's monarchy
questions.explanation: Samuel’s writing and laying the kingdom’s manner before the LORD in 1 Samuel 10:25 symbolizes a covenantal agreement, showing that the monarchy is under divine law and oversight.

questions.question: How does the behavior of the 'children of Belial' in 1 Samuel 10:27 contrast with the divine endorsement of Saul?
options: They reject Saul and show contempt despite God's choice
They celebrate Saul as the rightful king
They offer gifts to Saul to gain favor
They prophesy alongside Saul
questions.correctAnswer: They reject Saul and show contempt despite God's choice
questions.explanation: In 1 Samuel 10:27, the children of Belial despise Saul and refuse to honor him, illustrating human opposition to divine authority and foreshadowing challenges in Saul’s reign.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'Spirit of the LORD' coming upon Saul and enabling him to prophesy, as described in 1 Samuel 10:6 and 10?
options: It signifies Saul’s divine empowerment for leadership and prophetic confirmation
It means Saul becomes a priest
It indicates Saul’s entrance into the temple service
It predicts Saul’s failure as king
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies Saul’s divine empowerment for leadership and prophetic confirmation
questions.explanation: The Spirit of the LORD coming upon Saul in 1 Samuel 10:6 and 10 marks a transformation and divine endorsement, equipping him with prophetic abilities as a sign of God's empowerment for his kingship.

questions.question: How does the anointing of Saul in 1 Samuel 10 serve as a typology for the later anointing of kings in Israel’s history?
options: It sets a precedent of divine selection and Spirit empowerment
It was a unique event with no further significance
It was a political ritual without spiritual meaning
It foreshadows the building of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It sets a precedent of divine selection and Spirit empowerment
questions.explanation: Saul’s anointing in 1 Samuel 10 typifies the biblical pattern where God chooses kings through anointing with oil and Spirit empowerment, a motif repeated with David and others.

questions.question: True or False: In 1 Samuel 10, Saul openly discusses the matter of the kingdom with his uncle after meeting Samuel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: According to 1 Samuel 10:16, Saul told his uncle that Samuel only spoke about the found asses but did not reveal the matter of the kingdom, showing Saul’s discretion or the secretive nature of the anointing.

questions.question: Which ancient cultural practice is reflected in Samuel’s seven-day waiting period at Gilgal before revealing God's instructions to Saul (1 Samuel 10:8)?
options: Sacrificial and ritual preparation for leadership
A period of mourning for lost donkeys
A military training exercise
A time for political negotiation
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrificial and ritual preparation for leadership
questions.explanation: The seven-day period in 1 Samuel 10:8 involving burnt offerings and sacrifices reflects ancient Near Eastern customs of ritual purification and consecration before assuming significant roles.

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 10 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 10 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What significant act did Samuel perform to anoint Saul as captain over God's inheritance?
options: Poured oil on his head and kissed him
Placed a crown on his head
Wrote his name in the Book of Life
Offered a burnt offering for him
questions.correctAnswer: Poured oil on his head and kissed him
questions.explanation: Samuel poured oil on Saul's head and kissed him as a sign of anointing him as leader over God's inheritance, indicating God's chosen king (1 Samuel 10:1). This act of anointing with oil is consistent with God's appointment of leaders in Scripture (Exodus 29:7; 1 Kings 19:16; Psalm 89:20; Luke 4:18).

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 10, what would signal to Saul that the LORD was with him?
options: The fulfillment of specific signs Samuel described
A mighty army following him
Receiving abundant wealth
Immediate coronation by the elders
questions.correctAnswer: The fulfillment of specific signs Samuel described
questions.explanation: Samuel told Saul to observe the signs he would encounter and act accordingly because God was with him (1 Samuel 10:7). This echoes biblical teaching on discerning God's confirmation through signs (Judges 6:17; Isaiah 7:11; Acts 2:17-18; Hebrews 2:4).

questions.question: What transformation occurred in Saul after he departed from Samuel, according to the chapter?
options: God gave him another heart
He gained supernatural strength
He was clothed in royal garments
He received the gift of prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: God gave him another heart
questions.explanation: God gave Saul another heart, symbolizing a spiritual renewal and change of disposition (1 Samuel 10:9). This transformation aligns with God’s work of renewing hearts (Ezekiel 36:26; Psalm 51:10; 2 Corinthians 5:17; Ezekiel 11:19).

questions.question: Where did Saul meet a company of prophets and begin to prophesy?
options: On the hill of God
At Rachel's sepulchre
In Gilgal
At the plain of Tabor
questions.correctAnswer: On the hill of God
questions.explanation: Saul met a company of prophets on the hill of God and the Spirit of the LORD came upon him, enabling him to prophesy (1 Samuel 10:5-6,10). This illustrates the Spirit’s empowerment for prophetic ministry (Numbers 11:25; 1 Samuel 19:20-24; Acts 2:17; Joel 2:28-29).

questions.question: What was the people's reaction when they saw Saul prophesying among the prophets?
options: They questioned if Saul was also a prophet
They immediately crowned him king
They rejected him as unfit
They ignored the event
questions.correctAnswer: They questioned if Saul was also a prophet
questions.explanation: The people were amazed and questioned, 'Is Saul also among the prophets?' (1 Samuel 10:11). This reflects the unexpectedness of God's Spirit empowering leaders (Numbers 11:26-29; 1 Samuel 19:20-24; Acts 10:38; 1 Corinthians 12:7-11).

questions.question: How did Samuel describe Israel’s request for a king in relation to their relationship with God?
options: As a rejection of God who saved them
As a wise and timely request
As a fulfillment of prophecy
As a necessary political move
questions.correctAnswer: As a rejection of God who saved them
questions.explanation: Samuel declared that by asking for a king, the people had rejected God who had saved them from their enemies (1 Samuel 10:19). This highlights the theological principle that God alone is Israel's true King (Deuteronomy 17:14-20; 1 Samuel 8:7; Psalm 89:27-37; John 18:36).

questions.question: What method did Samuel use to select the tribe and family from which the king would come?
options: Casting lots
Consulting the elders
Divine revelation by prophecy
Voting by the people
questions.correctAnswer: Casting lots
questions.explanation: Samuel caused the tribes, families, and individuals to come near and selected Saul by casting lots (1 Samuel 10:20-21). Casting lots was a common biblical practice for discerning God's will (Leviticus 16:8; Proverbs 16:33; Jonah 1:7; Acts 1:26).

questions.question: Where was Saul found after initially hiding himself among the stuff?
options: Among the baggage and equipment
In a secret cave
At his father’s house
In the city gate
questions.correctAnswer: Among the baggage and equipment
questions.explanation: The LORD revealed that Saul had hidden himself among the stuff, interpreted as baggage or equipment, and he was fetched from there (1 Samuel 10:22-23). This shows God's knowledge of human actions and the unfolding of His sovereign plan (Psalm 139:2; Jeremiah 23:24; Proverbs 15:3; Isaiah 40:13-14).

questions.question: What characteristic distinguished Saul physically when he stood among the people?
options: He was taller than any of the people from shoulders upward
He had a radiant face like Moses
He wore a unique robe of blue
He was the youngest of the tribe
questions.correctAnswer: He was taller than any of the people from shoulders upward
questions.explanation: Saul was distinguished by his height, being taller than any of the people from shoulders upward (1 Samuel 10:23). Physical stature here symbolizes the visible choice of God’s anointed (Genesis 6:4; 1 Samuel 9:2; Isaiah 3:1; Matthew 17:2).

questions.question: What proclamation did the people make upon recognizing Saul as chosen by the LORD?
options: God save the king
Long live Saul
Peace be upon Israel
Blessed be Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: God save the king
questions.explanation: The people shouted 'God save the king' recognizing Saul as the LORD’s chosen one (1 Samuel 10:24). This acclamation acknowledges God’s sovereign rule through His anointed (Psalm 20:9; Psalm 72:17; Romans 13:1; Revelation 19:16).

questions.question: What did Samuel do after the people accepted Saul as king?
options: Told the manner of the kingdom and wrote it in a book
Immediately crowned Saul with a crown
Led a battle against the Philistines
Offered a sacrifice on Saul’s behalf
questions.correctAnswer: Told the manner of the kingdom and wrote it in a book
questions.explanation: Samuel instructed the people on the kingdom’s manner and wrote it in a book, laying it before the LORD (1 Samuel 10:25). This act symbolizes covenantal responsibility and accountability before God (Deuteronomy 17:14-20; Joshua 24:26; 2 Chronicles 34:14; Revelation 20:12).

questions.question: What was the response of some men described as 'children of Belial' toward Saul’s kingship?
options: They despised him and brought him no presents
They supported him with gifts and honor
They fled to another tribe
They conspired to assassinate him
questions.correctAnswer: They despised him and brought him no presents
questions.explanation: The children of Belial despised Saul, doubting his ability to save them and withheld gifts (1 Samuel 10:27). This illustrates opposition to God’s anointed, a theme throughout Scripture (Psalm 2:1-3; Isaiah 53:3; John 15:18-19; Acts 7:51).

questions.question: What role does the Spirit of the LORD play in Saul's commissioning as king in this chapter?
options: Empowers Saul to prophesy and transforms him into another man
Guarantees Saul's immediate military victory
Ensures Saul will never sin
Reveals future events to Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Empowers Saul to prophesy and transforms him into another man
questions.explanation: The Spirit of the LORD comes upon Saul, enabling him to prophesy and causing a transformation (1 Samuel 10:6,10). This demonstrates divine empowerment for leadership and prophetic gifting (Numbers 11:25; Judges 6:34; Isaiah 61:1; Acts 10:38).

questions.question: What theological principle is illustrated by God giving Saul 'another heart'?
options: God's sovereign ability to change human nature and purpose
The importance of human effort in leadership
The necessity of physical strength for kingship
That Saul was perfect and without sin
questions.correctAnswer: God's sovereign ability to change human nature and purpose
questions.explanation: God gave Saul another heart, illustrating divine sovereignty in renewing and redirecting human will and nature (1 Samuel 10:9). This aligns with the biblical theme of regeneration and sanctification (Ezekiel 36:26; John 3:3-6; 2 Corinthians 5:17; Philippians 2:13).

questions.question: What is the significance of Samuel kissing Saul after anointing him?
options: It signified God’s acceptance and blessing upon Saul
It was a customary greeting with no special meaning
It symbolized Saul's marriage to the nation
It marked Saul as a prophet
questions.correctAnswer: It signified God’s acceptance and blessing upon Saul
questions.explanation: Samuel's kiss after anointing Saul symbolized God’s blessing and acceptance of Saul's leadership (1 Samuel 10:1). This act signified divine approval and commissioning (Genesis 27:26-27; 2 Samuel 14:33; Luke 15:20; Romans 16:16).
